tools.name: Boxshade
tools.note: Also available as a command line tool with `apt install boxshade`. See also rMSA which can automate running boxshade from within R

tools.name: ESPript
tools.note: Primarily a web interface but can download a binary for linux https://espript.ibcp.fr/ESPript/ESPript/esp_faq.php

tools.name: MView
tools.note: See also their web versions of clustal omega etc. which have similar outputs

tools.name: pyGenomeTracks
tools.note: See also https://pypi.org/project/gtracks/ which is a separate project that is powered by pyGenomeTracks

tools.name: SashimiPlot
tools.note: See also rmats2sashimiplot which uses MISO. MATS stands for Multivariate Analysis of Transcript Splicing

tools.name: gfaestus
tools.note: See demo video displaying GFF3 annotations on graph https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=A-HnKXIrJl4

tools.name: odgi draw + odgi viz + odgi inject
tools.note: Example from https://github.com/pangenome/pggb, see also gene arrow map https://odgi.readthedocs.io/en/latest/rst/tutorials/injecting_gene_arrows.html

tools.name: BLAST+ (reading -outfmt 0 pairwise output is the original CLI bioinformatics!)
pyBamView
tools.note: See supplementary info for more figures, supports padded SAM/BAM which is fairly rare

tools.name: Circos
tools.note: no official github to my knowledge

tools.name: IslandViewer and IslandPlot
tools.note: web app using it here https://pathogenomics.sfu.ca/islandviewer uses D3, SVG

tools.name: MapView
tools.note: links in original paper are dead, but URL provided here works

tools.name: TE-nest
tools.note: this was an online tool that does not appear to exist anymore see https://web.archive.org/web/20170712104431/http://www.plantgdb.org/tool/TEnest/. the github link is re-hosted source code also downloaded from archive.org

tools.name: JBrowse
tools.note: See also JBrowse plugin registry https://gmod.github.io/jbrowse-registry. Runs on the web or as a desktop app using Electron

tools.name: JBrowse 2
tools.note: See gallery for more examples https://jbrowse.org/jb2/gallery

tools.name: Kero-BROWSE
tools.note: Also can visualize basic synteny, see tracks e.g. https://kero.hgc.jp/tool/keyword.html#kero:chrX:153,724,868-153,744,762 human vs chimp

tools.name: WashU epigenomics browser
tools.note: The ReactJS is a redesign, there is also a legacy version. Note also, there are comparative features https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2022.11.29.518374v1

tools.name: Dotlet
tools.note: The original publication was 2000 but updated ~2020 with reactjs

tools.name: LinearDisplay.pl
tools.note: readme says to cite this paper

tools.name: PURPLE
tools.note: intermutation-distance rainfall plots/katagesis plots are not technically in genomic coordinates, but do indicate genomic cluster of variants

tools.name: bcftools roh
tools.note: Plots runs of homozygosity, has interactive plot-roh.py helper too

tools.name: mocha
tools.note: Has a full analysis pipeline associated with end result visualizations

tools.name: ALVIS (MSA viewer)
tools.note: Introduces sequence bundles concept, also see web app version https://www.ebi.ac.uk/goldman-srv/sequencebundles/ source code https://bitbucket.org/schwarzlab/alvis/src/master/

tools.name: Nextclade
tools.note: Related usage on nextstrain app also

tools.name: udon
tools.note: Uses an advanced data structure for pileup, so visually a basic example but likely just a small demo

tools.name: AnnoJ
tools.note: See list of instances of the browser here https://ecker.salk.edu/genome-browser/

tools.name: vega
tools.note: Mentioned in https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2021.07.02.450883v1.full.pdf also note: vega standards for vertebrate genome annotation database

tools.name: ProViz
tools.note: See also alphafold visualization as tracks http://slim.icr.ac.uk/projects/alphafold?page=alphafold_proviz_homepage

tools.name: MIRA
tools.note: orig paper also describes mira here http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.23.7465&rep=rep1&type=pdf

tools.name: oxford-plots
tools.note: Has nice description of a synteny pipeline here https://github.com/jherrero/oxford-plots/blob/master/examples/pig_X_Y.txt

tools.name: MEGA-X
tools.note: original paper from 1994 but actively updated. requires EULA for download

tools.name: AmpliconArchitect
tools.note: The term amplicon refers essentially to extrachromosomal DNA in cancer

tools.name: REViewer
tools.note: See also GraphAlignmentViewer, similar look and from illumina also

tools.name: GENESPACE
tools.note: Includes a powerful analysis pipeline, worth reading the paper

tools.name: ggplot2 manhattan plot
tools.note: This is not a preconfigured tool but a blog post tutorial with tidy data and ggplot2

tools.name: CGView
tools.note: See also CGView comparison tool and other related https://paulstothard.github.io/cgview_comparison_tool/

tools.name: EvolutionHighway
tools.note: The 'evolutionary highway' image type is reproduced in some other packages e.g. https://github.com/marta-fb/syntenyPlotteR, paper https://doi.org/10.1126/science.1111387

tools.name: CIAlign
tools.note: Has useful utility functions to clean gaps and trim MSAs

tools.name: Argo
tools.notes: See also the tool 'Combo', a comparative version

tools.name: PhenoGram
tools.note: Can be web server or download

tools.name: local-rearrangements
tools.note: Can color dotplots with annotations for e.g. exons, transposons, low complexity regions. See also last-dotplot. Nice figure using it here https://genomemedicine.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/s13073-020-00762-1/figures/4

tools.name: SODA
tools.note: Describes itself as a low-level library to create larger applications with

tools.name: JBR
tools.note: Not open source, at least not on github

tools.name: clonifier
tools.note: per github: 'A web app for viewing plasmid maps & genomes, and simulating PCR and Gibson assembly'

tools.name: wally
tools.note: Available via the web from compiling to wasm

tools.name: pixy
tools.note: The link in readthedocs shows a nice general purpose way to plot multi-chromosome plots in ggplot2 with facet grid. Alternative methods for multi-chromosome plots shown by the manhattan ggplot2 tutorial (https://danielroelfs.com/blog/how-i-create-manhattan-plots-using-ggplot/ uses cumulative bp instead of facet_grid)

tools.name: Taxonium
tools.note: Genome variation visualisation in Taxonium is provided by the 'Treenome Viewer': https://academic.oup.com/bioinformatics/article/39/1/btac772/6858450

tools.name: odp (oxford dot plots)
tools.note: Pub is not for visualization tool, but it is suggested to cite this paper

tools.name: waragraph
tools.note: Deployed to the web via wasm

tools.name: gff2ps
tools.note: Used to make original figures for the human Celera genome

tools.name: AGFusion
tools.note: See also https://www.agfusion.app/ for web based version

tools.name: locuszoomr
tools.note: See also easylabel for manhattan plots https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/easylabel/vignettes/easylabel.html
